title: Trump tariffs drove a Treasury sell-off — who sold the safe-haven asset?
summary: In just a few sessions, yield on the 10-year Treasury soared to 4.592% on Friday, the highest since February, while the 30-year notched its highest since November 2023 last Wednesday.

title: How market returns' time of day & day of week trends are shifting
summary: Market (^GSPC, ^IXIC, ^DJI) behavior has shifted recently, with gains increasingly driven by overnight trading and event-driven volatility disrupting traditional patterns during regular hours. Yahoo Finance Markets and Data Editor Jared Blikre joins Catalysts to discuss how time-of-day and day-of-week dynamics influence price action in today's market. Catch more Stocks in Translation here, with new episodes every Tuesday and Thursday. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Catalysts here.

title: 1 Spectacular Vanguard ETF to Buy With $550 During the Tech Bear Market
summary: The S&P 500 (SNPINDEX: ^GSPC) is made up of 500 companies from 11 different economic sectors.  The information technology sector is the largest by a wide margin, representing 29.9% of the entire value of the index.  The S&P 500 recently suffered a peak-to-trough decline of 19%, falling just shy of the bear-market threshold of 20%.

title: Stock Market Sell-Off: 2 Dirt Cheap Dividend Stocks to Buy Now
summary: The S&P 500 (SNPINDEX: ^GSPC) is down 10% so far this year.  Let's discuss some reasons why Realty Income (NYSE: O) and Dollar General (NYSE: DG) could make great long-term buys.  Since its founding in 1969, Realty Income has grown to become America's eighth-largest real estate investment trust (REIT) -- a type of business structure that allows a company to avoid taxes if it returns 90% of its income to shareholders through a dividend.

title: Global investors dump holdings of US stocks at record pace, BofA survey says
summary: Respondents to BofA's monthly survey of fund managers were a net 36% underweight U.S. equities, the most in nearly two years, a number that has plunged by 53 percentage points since February, the biggest such fall on their records.  The trend looks set to continue, as a record number of respondents also said they intended to cut allocations to U.S. equities.  U.S. President Donald Trump's aggressive tariff plans have sparked a selloff in U.S. assets, including stocks, the dollar and Treasury bonds.
